Its been a wild month, everyone. Topics for Socratic Seminar #18, hot off the press. See you tomorrow night at NCR! https://atlantabitdevs.org/2023/05/30/bitcoin-socratic-seminar-18/

Bitcoin Socratic Seminar 18 - Atlanta BitDevs: Its almost time for Bitcoin Socratic Seminar 18! What is a Socratic Seminar? Inspired by other BitDevs meetups around the US, our Socratic Seminar events are formatted to foster debate, information sharing and lively discussion. Discussion topics are provided ahead of the event The event moderator(s) leads the audience through the topics Raise your hand to… Continue reading Bitcoin Socratic Seminar 18

Parking Instructions for NCR - Atlanta BitDevs. Here are instructions for getting to NCR for Atlanta BitDevs Socratic Seminars. Rideshare or Public Transit If you are taking rideshare or public transit, then you can use the main building address to navigate there. NCR Global Headquarters, 864 Spring St NW, Atlanta, GA 30308 Use the entrance on the Spring St side of the… Continue reading Parking Instructions for NCR

My contributions so far to the community are a DIY hww built from an esp32 that prints burner wallets en masse on thermal paper… and a vending machine controller that runs on Strike, Bitcoin Core and Liquid Core.

Anyways. I am probably overly chatty for a newbie. Hope you all have a good night. Thanks for the warm welcome

For those of you wondering about how many seminars Chaincode runs in a year, I asked Adam Jonas, who said “3-4 [seminars] in a year. We run them once we have enough demand so more applicants mean we will run them more often.” 

If you’re interested in participating in a seminar, I encourage you to go apply here: https://chaincode.applytojob.com/apply/9I75v7voVu/Chaincode-Labs-Bitcoin-Protocol-Development-Seminar-Virtual
Feel free to contact me if you need help with the application process.

Feel free to contact me if you need help with the application process. There is a mild technical portion to the application, but I don’t want that to prevent ppl from being considered, so lmk if you’re applying but don’t know how to code / are a beginner coder and I’ll help you with that portion.
Applied. Let's go!

Hey all - I'm looking for a really strong crypto / BD person to manage our hosted customers and also do equipment deals etc. If you know anyone can you let me know. We are a crypto mining company Soluna.io
Hey Phillip, thanks for the post. I’m curious, what is Soluna mining?

We build crypto data centers with wind power assets. They balance the grid, secure the blockchain, and improve the economics of wind power allowing for additional wind resources to come online.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BAfKgf2tXkg&t=6s
And we are mining Bitcoin mostly. I misunderstood your question. We used to mine ETH, have also mined LTC, BCH, DOGE, adn SIA coin.
cool cool. thanks for the background. sounds very cool! glad to see more renewable mining operations going on.

Here’s a link for MVCC from last night, the internal database checkpointing system used by Oracle and PostgreSQL, etc.

To put things in perspective, UCB Prof & entrepreneur Michael Stonebraker was at the forefront of these developments. Postgres is so named because the first academic db research project called Ingress had already begun commercialization, so they were exceedingly creative in their next name. 🤷🏻‍♂️🙄🤣🤦🏻‍♂️

All this development and research was nearly contemporaneous with the development of TCP/IP and the BSD versions of Unix. Which begat the Unix Wars and which prompted the development of “Unix compatible” Linux.

No Unix Wars, no Linux. Try to imagine that 🤷🏻‍♂️

Heck, MicroSoft was an early leader in Unix systems via their Xenix platform. Oh well … Gates was smart enough to recognize Unix wouldn’t work as a mass market product and they got lucky as fuck with DEC laying off Dave Cutler and the VMS operating system team, which MSFT hired immediately for what we know today as NT. Boom 💥 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiversion_concurrency_control

Lastly here’s a link for Paxos consensus algorithm.

Famously put into service by Google via their Big Table, Megastore & Spanner subsystems, which allowed for the creation of Gmail and their portfolio of consumer products.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paxos_(computer_science)

q: does silent payments proposal require a softfork / bip?

a: my knowledge is limited on the history of this proposal, but looking at the bip spec, it seems like it would not require a soft fork, but would require new/different client wallet sw. would love to learn more about this if anyone else knows more.

a: my knowledge is limited on the history of this proposal, but looking at the bip spec, it seems like it would not require a soft fork since it appears to be using primitives compatible with current on chain activity, but would require new/different client wallet sw. would love to learn more about this if anyone else knows more.

Good morning ATL BitDevs! Just wanted to make a reminder that TAB Conf is coming up in September, and this year, all content (talks, workshops, builder day tables, etc) is OPEN SOURCE. What does that mean? It means TAB continues to lean into its community-led, grassroots style by letting the plebs build the schedule. If you want to talk about something at TAB, go to the github repo, and use one of the templates to submit content. The org team is actively vetting all submissions from now until Setpember, and as we get closer, they will be selecting the talks that get the most engagement on GH (i.e. emojis, comments, etc). https://twitter.com/tabconf/status/1666824544039108611

If you’re not familiar with Adam Curry and No Agenda show, that’s where this came from. Adam was trying to go “OTG” (off the grid) and not be tracked by google so a listener made this website guide to installing Graphene on an android device.

Nice. Hopefully it's opened sourced, air gapped, allows for your own entropy to be used for seed generation, let's you use your own node and also supports P2PKH addresses / message singing. Otherwise I'll likely be sticking with coldcard. IMO minimizing your OPSEC sphere of trust in the bitcoin environment is always be top priority and so far combining coldcard and my own node with PSBTs seems to be the best approach in doing so.
